title: Flower Arranging — Introduction
description: The child learns to arrange flowers in a small vase, developing aesthetic sense, fine motor control, and care of the environment. This classic Montessori practical life activity teaches sequencing and encourages attention to beauty.
instructions:
1. Place tray with all materials: small vase, pitcher of water, three fresh flowers, scissors, small towel.
2. Demonstrate pouring water into the vase to halfway.
3. Show how to hold the scissors and trim the stem at an angle: 'We cut at a slant so the flower can drink more water.'
4. Place the first flower in the vase. Adjust the height.
5. Add the second and third, turning the vase to check from all sides.
6. Wipe any water drips with the towel. Choose where to display the arrangement.
materials_needed: 3 fresh flowers (carnations or daisies work well)
Newspaper or mat to protect surface

slides.heading: Flower Arranging
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to be flower arrangers today and make our space super pretty! We'll learn how to make a beautiful bouquet, just like the grown-ups do.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all materials on a tray. Place newspaper underneath to catch water drips. Have flowers lying flat on the tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the special things we need for our flower fun! We have a little vase for our flowers, a jug to pour water, three pretty flowers, and some scissors to trim them. We also have a soft towel for any little spills, and it's all on a big tray. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to arrange flowers to make our room beautiful!' Show the tray. 'First, we pour water into the vase — about halfway.' Demonstrate pouring slowly.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we need to give our flowers a drink! We're going to carefully pour some water into the vase. Hold the jug with both hands and tip it just a little bit, like you're making a tiny waterfall, until the vase is about halfway full.

slides.text: Pick up a flower. 'Hold it next to the vase to see how tall it should be. We want it a little taller than the vase.' Mark the spot with your finger.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's see how tall our flower should be. Hold one flower next to the vase and pretend you're giving it a haircut. We want it to be a little taller than the vase so it looks just right.

slides.text: Demonstrate cutting: 'Hold the stem here. Cut at a slant — like this.' Show the angled cut. 'The slanted end helps the flower drink more water.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is super important for our flower! We hold the stem and use the scissors to cut it at a little tilt, like a tiny slide. This special cut helps the flower drink lots and lots of water so it can stay happy.

slides.text: Place the flower in the vase. 'Now the second flower — a little shorter so we can see both. And the third!' Turn the vase. 'Does it look nice from every side?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, our first flower is ready! Now we gently put it in the vase. Let's add the next flower, maybe a little shorter this time, and then the third one. Turn the vase around slowly to see if it looks pretty from every single side.

slides.prompt: Now it is your turn! Trim each flower and arrange them in the vase. Turn the vase to check all sides. When you are happy, choose a special spot to display your arrangement.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's YOUR turn to be the flower artist! You get to carefully cut the stems and put the flowers in the vase. Remember to turn it and look from all the sides to make sure it's perfect. When you love how it looks, find a special spot to show off your beautiful creation!

slides.text: Wipe any water drips with the towel. Clean the workspace. 'You created something beautiful for our home! We will change the water every day to keep the flowers fresh.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child pour water, trim stems with scissors, and place flowers in a vase with minimal assistance?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job making our room beautiful! We used our special towel to wipe up any tiny drips, and now our flowers have a lovely home. We'll help them stay fresh by giving them new water every day. You are such a wonderful helper!

parent_notes: Flower arranging is a beloved Montessori practical life exercise that cultivates aesthetic appreciation and care of the environment. Maria Montessori believed that beauty in the environment nurtures the child's spirit. Let the child choose where to display the arrangement — this gives ownership and pride. Inexpensive grocery store flowers work perfectly. If fresh flowers are unavailable, use leafy branches or herbs from the garden. Change the water daily and invite the child to help, extending the lesson into ongoing care.

title: Sandpaper Letters — Group 4 (w, f, v)
description: Introduction to three new sandpaper letters: w, f, and v. The child traces the textured letters while saying the phonetic sounds, building the connection between the symbol and sound for these important consonants.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'w'. Trace with two fingers while saying /w/. Three-period lesson.
2. Present 'f'. Trace while saying /f/ (continuous breath sound). Three-period lesson.
3. Present 'v'. Trace while saying /v/ (voiced version of /f/). Three-period lesson.
4. Contrast f and v: 'Put your hand on your throat — /f/ is quiet, /v/ buzzes!'
5. Review all known letters (now 18).
6. Build new words with moveable alphabet: van, vet, fix, wag, win, web.
materials_needed: Small objects for I Spy (fan, vest, wig, vine, fig, fox)

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letters
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these special letters we're going to learn today! Their names are 'w', 'f', and 'v', and they make exciting sounds that help us read and write. We'll practice making their shapes with our fingers and saying their sounds, just like a super reader!

slides.setup_instructions: Present one letter at a time. Keep review letters in a basket. Have moveable alphabet ready on a mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we have for our letter adventure! We have our special bumpy sandpaper letters, a basket with other letters we already know, and a box of little letter pieces to build words. Ask a grown-up to help you get these ready so we can start playing!

slides.text: Letter 'w': trace the zig-zag shape with two fingers. '/w/ — like the beginning of water and wind.' Three-period lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to meet the letter 'w'! Feel its shape with your fingers as we trace it, like a wiggly wave. Say "/w/, /w/, /w/" with me, like the start of "water" and "wind" – brrr, it's windy!

slides.text: Letter 'f': trace the curve and crossbar. '/f/ — like the beginning of fish and fan.' Feel the breath on your hand!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here comes the letter 'f'! Let's trace its curvy shape with our fingers. Now, put your hand on your mouth and say "/f/, /f/, /f/" – feel the air blow out, just like when you blow out a birthday candle!

slides.text: Letter 'v': trace the two downward strokes. '/v/ — like the beginning of van and violin.' Put your hand on your throat — feel the buzz!
slides.mascot_explanation: And this is the letter 'v'! Trace its shape carefully with your fingers. Now, put your hand on your throat and say "/v/, /v/, /v/" – feel that little tickle, like a happy bumblebee buzzing inside!

slides.text: 'Let's compare /f/ and /v/. Your mouth is the same shape! But /v/ makes your throat vibrate. Try it!' This develops phonemic awareness.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's feel the difference between 'f' and 'v'! Make the shape for "/f/" and feel the air. Now make the shape for "/v/" and feel your throat buzz – isn't that neat how our mouths do it differently?

slides.prompt: Build these words with the moveable alphabet: van, vet, fix, wag, win, web. Read each word aloud. Can you think of more words with w, f, or v?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these letter pieces! We're going to build some super cool words like "van," "vet," and "web." Let's put the letters together, say the sounds, and read the words we make – you're becoming a word builder!

slides.text: 'Three more letter sounds! You now know 18 sounds. You are building so many words!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace, produce the sounds of w, f, and v, and distinguish between /f/ and /v/?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! We learned three brand new letter sounds: /w/, /f/, and /v/, and now you know 18 sounds in total! You are such a smart helper, and you're getting so good at building words and making sounds!

parent_notes: The voiced/voiceless pair f and v is a wonderful opportunity to explore how sounds are made. Have the child place a hand on their throat to feel the vibration of /v/ versus the breathiness of /f/. This is phonemic awareness in action — understanding that tiny differences in sound production create entirely different letters. The letter w has a complex shape; some children find it tricky to trace. Let them practice in a sand tray if the sandpaper letter is difficult. With 18 letters, the child can now build hundreds of words!

title: Golden Beads — Introduction to the Decimal System
description: The child is introduced to the golden bead material, learning the names and quantities of units, tens, hundreds, and thousands. This is the foundational lesson for the Montessori decimal system, giving concrete experience with place value.
instructions:
1. Lay a large mat on the floor.
2. Present a single golden bead: 'This is one UNIT.' Let the child hold it.
3. Present a ten bar: 'Ten units make one TEN. Count the beads — 1, 2, 3... 10!'
4. Present a hundred square: 'Ten tens make one HUNDRED. Feel how flat it is. Count the rows!'
5. Present a thousand cube: 'Ten hundreds make one THOUSAND. Feel how heavy it is!'
6. Naming game: 'Show me a ten. Show me a hundred. What is this called?'
materials_needed: Golden bead material (units, ten bars, hundred squares, thousand cube)

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn about special golden beads that help us understand big numbers. They are called units, tens, hundreds, and thousands, and they are like building blocks for numbers!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the mat on the floor. Have all golden bead categories in a tray. Present one category at a time from left to right.
slides.mascot_explanation: To play with our special beads, we need a big mat to spread them out on. We also need the golden bead units, which are like tiny little beads, and some longer bars, flat squares, and a big cube made of beads. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things for our game?

slides.text: 'Today you are going to meet something very special — golden beads! They will teach you about BIG numbers.' Hold up one bead. 'This is one UNIT. It is small.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's start with our first special bead! This little golden bead is called a UNIT. It's just one, all by itself, like one little candy.

slides.text: Hold up a ten bar. 'When we put ten units together in a line, we get one TEN.' Let the child count the beads on the bar: '1, 2, 3... 10!' Place it next to the unit.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this long stick of beads? When we put ten of those little UNIT beads together, we make a TEN! Let's count them together: one, two, three... all the way to ten!

slides.text: Hold up a hundred square. 'When we put ten TENS together, we get one HUNDRED!' Count the rows: 'One ten, two tens... ten tens — one hundred!' Place it next to the ten bar.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, look at this flat square! When we put ten of those TEN sticks together, they make a HUNDRED! It's like a whole big group of tens all snuggled up together.

slides.text: Hold up the thousand cube. 'When we put ten HUNDREDS together, we get one THOUSAND! Feel how big and heavy it is.' Let the child hold it. Place it on the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: And this big, heavy cube is a THOUSAND! It's made when we put ten of those HUNDRED squares together. Feel how big and special it is!

slides.prompt: Three-period lesson: 'Show me a unit. Show me a hundred. What is this called?' Mix up the categories. Can you arrange them from smallest to biggest?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a game with our beads! Can you point to the one that is just a UNIT? Now, show me the HUNDRED square. What do you call this one? Let's try to put them in order from the smallest to the biggest!

slides.text: 'Unit, ten, hundred, thousand — you just learned how our number system works! Everything is built from these four groups.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify, name, and order all four categories of golden beads (unit, ten, hundred, thousand)?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a super job learning about the golden beads! You learned about the UNIT, the TEN, the HUNDRED, and the THOUSAND. You helped build our number system today!

parent_notes: The golden bead material is the heart of Montessori math for ages 4-6. It gives children a concrete, sensorial experience of the decimal system long before they encounter abstract place value. The progression from tiny unit bead to heavy thousand cube is deeply impressive to children. Let them hold, feel, and compare. If you do not have official golden beads, substitute: single beads or buttons for units, popsicle sticks bundled in tens, flat squares of 100 stickers, and a cube-shaped box for thousands. The key is the visual and tactile difference between categories.

title: Africa Puzzle Map — Introduction
description: The child explores the Africa puzzle map, learning the names of major countries and regions. Africa is the second-largest continent and home to incredible geographic diversity, from the Sahara Desert to tropical rainforests.
instructions:
1. Present the Africa puzzle map.
2. Remove each piece one at a time, naming the country. Start with large, recognizable ones: Egypt, South Africa, Democratic Republic of Congo, Nigeria.
3. Point out geographic features: 'The Sahara Desert covers the top third of Africa.'
4. Place pieces back, matching color to outline.
5. Discuss: 'Africa has more countries than any other continent — over 50!'
6. Color a blank outline map of Africa, marking the Sahara and the Nile River.

slides.heading: Africa
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This slide has the word "Africa" on it, and it says we're going to learn about a special puzzle map of Africa! It’s like a big puzzle of a whole continent where lots of people and animals live.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the puzzle map on a table or mat. Have the globe nearby to locate Africa in context.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our Africa adventure! We have a puzzle of Africa, a picture of what it looks like all put together, a plain map to color, some colorful pencils, and a big ball called a globe that shows the whole world. Ask a grown-up to help you find everything so we can start playing!

slides.text: 'Find Africa on the globe — the GREEN continent! Africa is the second biggest continent in the world.' Show it on the globe, then present the puzzle map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's find Africa on our globe together! See that big green shape? That's Africa, and it's super big, the second biggest place on our whole Earth! Now, let's put the puzzle map right here so we can explore it.

slides.text: Remove Egypt: 'This is Egypt, at the very top. The ancient pyramids are here!' Remove South Africa: 'This is at the very bottom — South Africa.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to take some puzzle pieces out! This piece is called Egypt, and it's way up at the tippy-top of Africa, where the super old pyramids are. And this piece down at the very bottom is South Africa, all the way at the end!

slides.text: Point to the Sahara region: 'This whole area is the Sahara Desert — the biggest hot desert on Earth! It is almost as big as all of the United States.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this big sandy spot on the map? That's the Sahara Desert, and it's the biggest, hottest desert on Earth! It's so big, it covers almost a whole third of Africa, like a giant sandy blanket.

slides.text: Replace pieces one by one. 'Africa has more than 50 countries — more than any other continent! Each piece is a country.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put our puzzle pieces back in their spots! Each piece is a different country, and Africa has more countries than anywhere else – over 50! It’s like a giant puzzle with lots and lots of little countries all fitting together.

slides.prompt: Color a blank Africa map. Mark the Sahara in yellow, the Nile River in blue, and color Egypt, South Africa, Nigeria, and Congo. Label what you can.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our own map of Africa! We'll color the big Sahara Desert yellow, and the long, wiggly Nile River blue, just like we learned. Then, we'll color in some special countries and write their names if we can.

slides.text: 'Africa is a continent of incredible diversity — deserts, rainforests, savannas, and so many countries and cultures!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate Africa on the globe, name at least 3 countries, and identify the Sahara Desert?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You learned all about Africa, like how it has huge deserts and lots and lots of countries. You were so good at finding Egypt and South Africa and telling me about the big Sahara Desert!

parent_notes: The Africa puzzle map introduces the child to the continent with the most countries — a wonderful opportunity for ongoing exploration. At this age, focus on a few landmark countries and major geographic features rather than memorizing all 54 nations. Egypt and the pyramids, the Sahara Desert, the Nile River, and African animals are natural hooks for young learners. Consider pairing this lesson with pictures of African animals or a short video of African landscapes to spark wonder. Montessori geography always moves from concrete (the puzzle pieces) to abstract (understanding the concept of countries and continents).

title: Read-Aloud: Planting a Rainbow by Lois Ehlert
description: Reading Lois Ehlert's vibrant book about planting bulbs and seeds that grow into a rainbow of flowers. This connects to the practical life flower arranging and science themes of plant growth.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What colors do you see? What do you think this book is about?'
2. Read slowly, pausing at each color section.
3. Name the flowers: 'These are tulips. These are daffodils. Do you know any of these flowers?'
4. Discuss the planting process: bulbs in fall, seeds in spring.
5. 'The family planted seeds and grew a whole rainbow! What colors would you plant?'
6. Optional: draw your own rainbow garden.
materials_needed: Planting a Rainbow by Lois Ehlert
Crayons and paper (optional, for drawing a garden)

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Planting a Rainbow by Lois Ehlert
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this pretty book cover! It's called "Planting a Rainbow," and it's full of colors. What colors do you see? What do you think this book might be about?

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably. Have crayons ready in case the child wants to draw afterward.
slides.mascot_explanation: To read our story, we need a few things! We need our special book, "Planting a Rainbow," and a super cozy spot to snuggle up. If you want to draw later, we can get crayons and paper ready too!

slides.text: Show the cover: 'Look at all these colors! This book is called Planting a Rainbow. What do you think they are planting?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the cover! It's so colorful. This book is called "Planting a Rainbow." What do you think the people in the story are planting to make a rainbow?

slides.text: Read slowly through each color section. 'Red flowers: tulips and poppies! Orange flowers: tiger lilies and marigolds!' Let the child name the colors.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read the story! We'll look at all the beautiful colors and learn the names of the flowers. Can you tell me what colors you see on this page?

slides.text: Discuss planting: 'Some flowers grow from bulbs — you plant them in the fall. Others grow from seeds in the spring. Both need soil, water, and sunshine.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part talks about how flowers grow. Some flowers start as little bulbs that we plant when it's cold outside. Other flowers grow from tiny seeds when it's warm. All plants need soil, water, and sunshine to grow big and strong!

slides.prompt: After reading: 'If you could plant a rainbow garden, what colors would you choose? What flowers?' Draw your dream garden with all the colors of the rainbow.
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine you could plant your very own rainbow garden! What colors would you pick for your flowers? What kind of flowers would you want to grow? Let's draw your amazing rainbow garden right now!

slides.text: 'Gardens are like living rainbows! Maybe we can plant some flowers of our own and watch them grow.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 flowers from the book and explain what plants need to grow?
slides.mascot_explanation: Our garden is like a beautiful, growing rainbow! We learned about so many flowers and how they need sun and water. Maybe we can plant some real flowers outside and watch our own rainbow grow!

parent_notes: This book pairs beautifully with the flower arranging practical life lesson this week. Lois Ehlert's bold, graphic collage art is very appealing to young children. The book naturally teaches color identification, plant names, and the gardening cycle. If possible, follow up by actually planting some flower seeds or bulbs. Children who participate in growing flowers develop a deep connection to nature and the patience required by the natural world — a core Montessori value.

title: Sound Cylinders — Introduction
description: The child explores the sound cylinders, matching pairs of cylinders that produce the same sound when shaken. This activity refines auditory discrimination and develops the ability to focus attention through the sense of hearing.
instructions:
1. Present two boxes of sound cylinders (one with red lids, one with blue lids).
2. 'Each cylinder makes a sound when you shake it. Listen carefully!' Shake one red cylinder gently near the ear.
3. Shake a blue cylinder. 'Does it sound the same? No — let's find the match.'
4. Demonstrate shaking and comparing until you find the matching pair.
5. Set matched pairs aside together.
6. The child continues matching all six pairs.
materials_needed: Sound cylinders (2 sets of 6 — red lids and blue lids)

slides.heading: Sound Cylinders
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to play a fun game with sounds today! We're going to use our super-listening ears to find sounds that are just the same. It’s like a sound guessing game!

slides.setup_instructions: Place red cylinders in a row on the left, blue on the right. Ensure the room is quiet so the child can listen carefully.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special cylinders! We have a set with red tops and a set with blue tops. We also have a special mat to put them on. Let’s get them ready on the mat so we can start our sound adventure!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use our ears — just our ears — to match sounds!' Pick up one red cylinder and shake it gently near your ear. 'Listen carefully to this sound.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let’s use our ears to listen! I’m going to pick up this red one and give it a little shake, just for our ears to hear. Listen very, very closely to the sound it makes. Shhh!

slides.text: Pick up a blue cylinder and shake it. 'Does this one sound the same? No? Let's try another blue one.' Continue until you find the match.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now I’m going to shake one of the blue ones. Does that sound like the red one we just heard? Hmm, maybe not. Let’s try another blue one and see if it sounds like the red one. We have to listen carefully!

slides.text: 'These two sound the same!' Place the matched pair together in the center. 'Now let's find the next match.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we found them! These two cylinders sound exactly the same when we shake them. We'll put these two buddies together right here in the middle. Now we know what a matching pair sounds like!

slides.text: Demonstrate one more pair, then invite the child: 'Your turn! Pick a red cylinder, listen carefully, and find its partner in the blue set.'
slides.mascot_explanation: I showed you how to find one pair, and now it's your turn to be the super listener! Pick any red cylinder you want, give it a gentle shake, and listen hard. Then, find its matching sound in the blue ones. You can do it!

slides.prompt: Match all six pairs by sound. Shake gently near your ear — listen closely! When all pairs are matched, can you put them in order from quietest to loudest?
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time for you to be the sound detective and match all the pairs! Give each cylinder a little shake next to your ear and listen super carefully. When you find two that sound the same, put them together. You are doing such a great job listening!

slides.text: 'Your ears can tell the difference between many different sounds! This is a special skill called careful listening.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 4 of the 6 sound cylinder pairs?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Your ears are so amazing at hearing tiny differences in sounds. We learned how to listen very carefully and match sounds, which is a super important skill for our brains! You were a fantastic sound detective today!

parent_notes: The sound cylinders isolate the sense of hearing, training the child to make fine auditory distinctions. This is directly connected to reading readiness — hearing the difference between similar speech sounds. Ensure the environment is quiet during this work. If you do not have official sound cylinders, make your own using identical opaque containers (film canisters, small bottles) filled with different materials: rice, beans, sand, salt, beads, and cotton balls. Make two of each. The child should shake gently and hold the cylinder near the ear, not vigorously. Grading from quietest to loudest is an advanced extension.

title: CVC Word Building — Expanding Vocabulary
description: The child builds and reads a wider variety of CVC words using the moveable alphabet, incorporating the newly learned letters w, f, and v alongside all previously known letters. Focus on reading fluency with three-letter words.
instructions:
1. Lay out the moveable alphabet on a mat.
2. Review: build 3 familiar CVC words (cat, sit, mop). Child reads each.
3. Introduce new words with w, f, v: wet, wag, fan, fig, vet, van.
4. Child builds each word as you say it slowly: '/w/-/e/-/t/ — wet!'
5. Mix old and new: 'Build the word I say.' Dictate 10 words randomly.
6. Extension: child picks an object, builds its CVC name.
materials_needed: Small objects whose names are CVC words (fan, wig, van, hat, cup, pig)

slides.heading: Word Building
slides.subheading: New Words with w, f, and v
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to play a word game and learn some new sounds. We'll be building words with letters like 'w', 'f', and 'v'. Get ready for some super fun word-building!

slides.setup_instructions: Spread the moveable alphabet on a mat. Place objects nearby. Have a list of CVC words ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: To play our game, we need a few things. See all these little letter tiles? Those are our moveable alphabet, and we'll put them on this big mat. We also have some little toys and a list for grown-ups. Ask your grown-up to help you get everything ready!

slides.text: 'Let's build words with our new letter sounds! Remember /w/, /f/, and /v/?' Quick review: child traces in the air or on the table.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's warm up our mouths for our new sounds! Can you make the 'w' sound like you're saying "wow"? Now try the 'f' sound, like blowing out a candle. And the 'v' sound, like a buzzing bee! Let's practice them together.

slides.text: '/w/-/e/-/t/ — can you hear the sounds? Find the letters and build the word.' Child selects w, e, t and places them in order. 'Read it! Wet!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to build our first new word! Listen closely: '/w/-/e/-/t/'. Can you find those letters? Put the 'w', then the 'e', then the 't' together. Great job! Now let's read it: "wet"!

slides.text: Continue: fan, fig, vet, van, wag. For each word, say it slowly, child builds it, then reads it back.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to do that for a few more words, just like we did "wet." We'll say the sounds slowly, like '/f/-/a/-/n/', and you find the letters to build "fan." Then we'll do "fig," "vet," "van," and "wag" too!

slides.text: Now mix in familiar words: 'Build cat. Build fig. Build hat. Build vet.' Speed increases as confidence grows.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to mix it up a little! I'll say a word, and you build it using the letters. We'll build some of the new words we just learned, and some words we already know, like "cat" and "hat." Let's see how fast you can build them!

slides.prompt: Pick an object from the basket. Can you build its name? Try: fan, wig, van, hat, cup, pig. Build all six and read them!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super fun part! See the little toys? Pick one up and say its name. Can you find the letters to build the word for that toy? We'll try to build six words together, like "fan" and "van," and then read them all!

slides.text: 'You can build and read so many words now! Every new letter gives you more word power.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently build and read at least 6 CVC words including words with w, f, and v?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job building and reading words today! You learned new sounds and made so many words. You have super word-building power now! Remember how you built all those tricky words? You're a word-building star!

parent_notes: Word building with the moveable alphabet is the Montessori bridge between knowing letter sounds and reading. The physical act of selecting letters and placing them in order reinforces left-to-right directionality and phonemic segmentation. Always say the word slowly, stretching the sounds, so the child can hear each phoneme. Do not rush to correct — if the child writes 'fan' as 'fn,' gently stretch the middle sound: '/f/-/aaa/-/n/ — do you hear the /a/ in the middle?' The child is both writing and reading simultaneously, which is powerful.

title: Golden Beads — Fetching Quantities
description: The child practices identifying and fetching specific quantities of golden bead material. This builds understanding of the decimal categories through active movement and reinforces the names of units, tens, hundreds, and thousands.
instructions:
1. Place the golden bead bank on a shelf across the room.
2. 'Please bring me 3 tens.' Child walks to the bank, counts 3 ten bars, brings them back.
3. Verify together by counting: '10, 20, 30 — yes, 3 tens!'
4. 'Now please bring me 5 units.' Child fetches 5 loose beads.
5. Increase complexity: 'Bring me 2 hundreds and 4 units.'
6. Always verify by counting together when the child returns.
materials_needed: Golden bead material (full bank: many units, tens, hundreds, and thousand cubes)

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to play a fun game with special golden beads today. It's called "Fetching Quantities," and it's going to be super exciting!

items: Full golden bead bank on a shelf
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the golden bead bank on a shelf away from the workspace. The child will walk back and forth fetching quantities — movement is part of the lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: See all these special things? We have a big golden bead bank far away, and we'll use this tray to carry things. We also have a special mat for our work. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things for our game?

slides.text: 'The golden bead bank is over there. I am going to ask you to bring me certain quantities. Ready?' This fetching game uses gross motor movement.
slides.mascot_explanation: Our special golden bead bank is way over there, across the room! I'm going to ask you to go get some special beads for me. Are you ready to play this fetching game?

slides.text: 'Please bring me 3 tens.' Child walks to the bank, selects 3 ten bars, places them on the tray, and carries them back.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, your first job is to go get me 3 of the long, skinny "ten" bars. Walk all the way to the bank, pick out 3 of those ten bars, put them on your tray, and bring them right back to me.

slides.text: Count together: 'One ten, two tens, three tens — 10, 20, 30! Perfect!' Celebrate accuracy.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Let's count them together! We have one ten, two tens, three tens. That makes 30! You got it exactly right, you are so smart!

slides.text: 'Now bring me 5 units.' Then: 'Bring me 2 hundreds.' Then challenge: 'Bring me 1 thousand, 2 hundreds, and 3 units!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try another one! Can you go get me 5 little single beads, called "units"? And then, can you bring me 2 of those big square "hundred" blocks? Maybe you can even try bringing me one giant "thousand" cube, two "hundred" blocks, and three "units"!

slides.prompt: Fetching game: your parent says a quantity, you bring it from the bank. Start simple and get bigger! Can you fetch 4 tens, 6 units, 2 hundreds, and 1 thousand?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our fetching game! I'll tell you how many beads to get, and you'll walk over to the bank and bring them back. We'll start with easy ones and then try bigger numbers, like fetching 4 tens and 6 units, or even 2 hundreds and 1 thousand!

slides.text: 'You can find ANY quantity in the golden bead bank! You know units, tens, hundreds, and thousands.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly fetch requested quantities of each category (units, tens, hundreds, thousands)?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job today! You showed me you can find any amount of beads in the golden bead bank. You are a super star at knowing your units, tens, hundreds, and thousands!

parent_notes: The fetching game is a brilliant Montessori strategy that incorporates movement into learning. Walking across the room to get materials gives the child time to think, requires them to hold the request in memory, and provides a physical break from seated work. Place the golden bead bank far enough away that the child must truly walk, not just reach. This lesson should feel like a fun game. Increase complexity gradually: start with single categories ('3 tens'), then combine ('2 hundreds and 5 units'). The child internalizes place value through this repetitive, joyful practice.

title: Life Cycle of a Butterfly
description: The child learns the four stages of a butterfly's life cycle: egg, caterpillar (larva), chrysalis (pupa), and adult butterfly. This lesson uses concrete materials to explore metamorphosis and connects to the natural world.
instructions:
1. Show pictures or figurines of each stage: egg, caterpillar, chrysalis, butterfly.
2. 'Every butterfly starts as a tiny egg on a leaf. What hatches from the egg?'
3. 'The caterpillar eats and eats and grows. Then something amazing happens — it makes a chrysalis!'
4. 'Inside the chrysalis, the caterpillar transforms into a butterfly!'
5. Arrange the stages in a circle (cycle): egg → caterpillar → chrysalis → butterfly → egg.
6. Draw and label the four stages.
materials_needed: Butterfly life cycle figurines or pictures
Optional: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle

slides.heading: Life Cycles
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Life Cycles," and it's all about how a beautiful butterfly grows up. We're going to learn a super cool secret today!

items: Butterfly life cycle figurines or pictures
Optional: The Very Hungry Caterpillar book
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange the four stages in order on a mat. If using figurines, place them on a tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these fun things we get to play with! We have little toys that look like the butterfly's whole family, and paper and crayons so we can draw them. We also have a special chart to help us remember, and maybe a book about a hungry caterpillar! Ask your grown-up to help you find these to get ready.

slides.text: 'Have you ever seen a butterfly? Today we are going to learn how a butterfly is born!' Show the tiny egg. 'A mother butterfly lays a tiny egg on a leaf.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this tiny little speck on the leaf? That's where our butterfly story begins! A mommy butterfly carefully lays a teeny-tiny egg, and that's how it all starts.

slides.text: Show the caterpillar. 'From the egg hatches a caterpillar — also called a larva. It eats leaves and grows bigger and bigger!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Poof! Out of the egg comes a wiggly caterpillar! This little guy loves to munch, munch, munch on leaves and gets bigger and bigger. He's like a tiny eating machine!

slides.text: Show the chrysalis. 'The caterpillar wraps itself in a chrysalis — like a sleeping bag! Inside, something magical happens. Its whole body changes!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, the caterpillar does something amazing. It makes a cozy little house called a chrysalis, like a special sleeping bag. Inside, it rests and changes in a secret way.

slides.text: Show the butterfly. 'Out comes a BUTTERFLY! This change is called metamorphosis — meta-mor-pho-sis. It means a big change.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Ta-da! When it's ready, out pops a beautiful butterfly! This whole big change, from a wiggly caterpillar to a flying butterfly, is called metamorphosis. Isn't that a fun word to say?

slides.prompt: Draw the four stages in a circle: egg, caterpillar, chrysalis, butterfly. Label each one. Draw arrows showing the cycle goes round and round!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to make a butterfly circle! Let's draw the tiny egg, then the hungry caterpillar, then the cozy chrysalis, and finally, the beautiful butterfly. We can draw arrows to show how it goes round and round, like a never-ending story!

slides.text: 'A butterfly goes through four amazing stages. Can you name them all? Egg, caterpillar, chrysalis, butterfly!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and sequence all four stages of the butterfly life cycle?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You remembered all the amazing steps a butterfly takes: the egg, the caterpillar, the chrysalis, and the butterfly! You're a super scientist now!

parent_notes: Metamorphosis is one of the most awe-inspiring phenomena in nature, and children are naturally fascinated by it. If possible, order a butterfly kit (painted lady caterpillars) so the child can observe the full life cycle over several weeks. This transforms an abstract lesson into direct experience — the highest form of Montessori learning. The word 'metamorphosis' is long but children love big words! Let them practice saying it. Connect this to The Very Hungry Caterpillar if you have it. The key concept is that a life CYCLE goes in a circle — the butterfly lays eggs that start the process again.

title: Collage — Nature Collection
description: The child creates a collage using collected natural materials such as leaves, petals, small sticks, and seeds. This integrates art with science and encourages observation of natural textures, colors, and shapes.
instructions:
1. Go on a short nature walk to collect materials: leaves, flower petals, small twigs, seed pods, grass.
2. Back inside, lay out the collection on a tray.
3. Provide a sturdy piece of cardboard or thick paper as the base.
4. Demonstrate applying glue and pressing a leaf onto the paper.
5. 'Arrange your natural materials however you like — you are the artist!'
6. Let dry. Discuss the textures and colors used.
materials_needed: Collected natural materials (leaves, petals, twigs, seeds)

slides.heading: Nature Collage
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make something super special called a "Nature Collage." That means we're going to use pretty things we find outside to make a picture!

slides.setup_instructions: Collect materials from a nature walk beforehand or as part of the lesson. Lay them out sorted by type on a tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our art, we need some special things! We need the cool leaves and flowers and little sticks we found outside. We also need some thick paper and glue to stick everything down. Can you help ask a grown-up to get all these things ready for us?

slides.text: 'Look at all the beautiful things we found outside! We are going to use them to make art.' Show the collection: leaves, petals, twigs, seeds.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all the wonderful treasures we found on our walk! We have soft leaves, pretty flower petals, and maybe even some tiny sticks. We're going to use all these amazing things from nature to make our art today!

slides.text: Demonstrate: 'I put a little glue on my paper, then press the leaf down. Hold it for a moment.' Let the child feel the different textures.
slides.mascot_explanation: See how I put a little bit of glue on the paper? Then I take a leaf and press it down gently. We need to hold it for just a little while so it sticks super well. You can feel how the leaf feels, too – is it smooth or bumpy?

slides.text: 'Now it is your turn! You can arrange the materials however you like. You are the artist — there is no wrong way to create!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the artist! You can pick any of the nature treasures you like and put them on your paper. You get to decide where everything goes, and there's no wrong way to make your art!

slides.prompt: Create your nature collage! Arrange leaves, petals, twigs, and seeds on your paper. Glue them down. Make any design you like — a scene, a pattern, or something abstract.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's make our own beautiful nature collage! Pick your favorite leaves, petals, and sticks, and put them on your paper. Then, use the glue to stick them down all over. You can make any picture you want!

slides.text: 'Look at your nature art! Every piece came from the living world. What textures can you feel? Smooth? Rough? Bumpy?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently apply glue and arrange materials to create a collage?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your amazing art! You used all these special things from nature to make something beautiful. Can you feel how different the textures are – some are smooth and some are a little rough? You did such a great job!

parent_notes: Nature collage beautifully integrates art and science. The child practices classification (sorting materials), fine motor control (applying glue, placing small items), and aesthetic judgment (arranging the composition). Maria Montessori believed that art should connect children to nature. Avoid giving a template — let the child create freely. Some may make a representational scene (a tree, a garden), while others will create abstract patterns. Both are valid. If you want to preserve the collage, cover it with clear contact paper once dry. This activity can be repeated seasonally to observe how available materials change.

title: Food Preparation — Spreading on Crackers
description: The child practices the skill of spreading soft foods (cream cheese or hummus) onto crackers using a small spreading knife. This develops fine motor control, wrist rotation, and the independence of preparing one's own snack.
instructions:
1. Wash hands together.
2. Arrange tray: small bowl of cream cheese or hummus, plate of crackers, spreading knife, napkin.
3. Demonstrate: hold cracker in non-dominant hand, scoop a small amount with the knife.
4. Spread with gentle back-and-forth strokes: 'Spread from the middle outward. Not too much pressure or the cracker breaks!'
5. Show the finished cracker. Take a bite!
6. Child spreads the remaining crackers independently.
materials_needed: Cream cheese, hummus, or soft butter

slides.heading: Food Preparation
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at our special title! Today, we're going to be super chefs and make our own yummy snack by spreading things on crackers. It's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Wash hands first. Arrange everything on a tray. Use a sturdy cracker that will not break easily under pressure.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need to make our snack! We have some crunchy crackers, some yummy cream cheese or hummus to spread, and a special little knife for spreading. We also need a bowl, a plate, and a napkin for when we're all done. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get all these things ready!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to make our own snack! We will spread cream cheese on crackers.' Show the materials.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to make our own snack today! We're going to put some yummy cream cheese or hummus on our crackers, like a little topping. It's like decorating a tiny edible picture!

slides.text: Demonstrate: 'Hold the cracker flat in this hand. Use the knife to scoop a small amount.' Show how much — about a marble-sized portion.
slides.mascot_explanation: See how I'm holding the cracker with one hand, nice and steady? Then, I take my special knife and scoop just a little bit of the cream cheese, like a tiny white cloud. We don't want too much, just a little bit to spread.

slides.text: 'Now spread gently — back and forth, from the middle out to the edges. Gentle, gentle! If we press too hard, the cracker breaks.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we use our gentle hands to spread the cream cheese from the middle of the cracker all the way to the edges. We go back and forth softly, like we're painting! If we push too hard, our cracker might get a boo-boo and break.

slides.text: 'Look! A perfectly spread cracker. Let's take a bite. Mmm!' Now invite the child: 'Your turn to make one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Ta-da! Look at my perfectly spread cracker! It's ready for a yummy bite. Now it's your turn to try making one yourself, and then you can taste your own delicious creation!

slides.prompt: Spread cream cheese on 4-5 crackers. Try to cover the whole cracker evenly without breaking it. Enjoy your snack when done!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to be the chef! Let's spread the creamy yummy stuff on all your crackers, trying to cover them nicely without breaking them. When you're all done, you get to eat your amazing snack!

slides.text: Clean up: wipe the knife, put the bowl and plate on the tray, wipe the table. 'You made your own snack — that is real independence!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child scoop an appropriate amount and spread evenly without breaking crackers?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job making your own snack! We cleaned up our special tools, and you learned how to spread all by yourself. That's super grown-up and super cool!

parent_notes: Spreading is a core Montessori food preparation skill that develops the same wrist rotation used in writing. The key challenge is pressure control — too much and the cracker snaps, too little and the spread does not move. This is excellent proprioceptive feedback. Choose sturdy crackers (water crackers or thick rice cakes work well) to reduce frustration. If a cracker breaks, calmly say, 'That happens sometimes. Let's try again with a little less pressure.' Never rush the child. The reward of eating what they prepare is powerful intrinsic motivation.

title: Phonogram Awareness — Introduction to 'sh'
description: The child is introduced to the concept that two letters can work together to make one sound. The phonogram 'sh' is presented first because it is visually distinct and aurally clear. This builds the foundation for reading beyond CVC words.
instructions:
1. 'You know the sounds /s/ and /h/. But when s and h are next to each other, they make a NEW sound: /sh/!'
2. Present the 'sh' double sandpaper letter (or write 'sh' on card). Trace while saying /sh/.
3. I Spy: find objects with /sh/ — ship, shell, shoe, fish, dish, bush.
4. Build words with moveable alphabet: ship, shop, shin, shed, fish, dish, wish, mash.
5. Read the words back. 'These letters always say /sh/ when they are together.'
materials_needed: Objects with /sh/ sound (shell, ship figurine, shoe)

slides.heading: Phonograms
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this page! It has big words that tell us what we're going to learn. We're going to learn about a special sound that letters make together.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the 'sh' card ready. Place sh-objects in a basket. Lay out the moveable alphabet on a large mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need for our game! We have letters that feel bumpy, like the 'sh' letters, and lots of other little letters to play with. We also have some cool toys like a shell and a shoe. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get everything ready!

slides.text: 'You know /s/ and you know /h/. But something special happens when they come together. Listen: /sh/!' Put finger to lips. 'Like when we say shhh — be quiet!'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know the sound 'ssss' and the sound 'hhhh', right? Well, when those two letters get together, they make a brand new sound: '/sh/!' It's like when we whisper 'shhh' to be quiet. Put your finger on your lips and let's say it together: /sh/.

slides.text: Show the 'sh' card. 'These two letters together always say /sh/. Trace them with me.' The child traces both letters as one sound.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the special letters, 's' and 'h'. When they hold hands, they make the '/sh/' sound. Let's trace them with our fingers, just like this, and say the sound together: /sh/. They are a team!

slides.text: I Spy: 'I spy something that starts with /sh/ — you wear it on your foot!' (shoe). 'I spy something that ends with /sh/ — you find it at the beach!' (shell).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to play a fun game of "I Spy"! I spy something you wear on your foot that starts with the '/sh/' sound – can you guess? It's a shoe! And I spy something you can find at the beach that ends with the '/sh/' sound – it's a shell!

slides.text: 'Let's build /sh/ words!' Build 'ship' together: s-h-i-p. 'The s and h work as a team!' Build shop, shed, fish, dish, wish.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to build some words using our special letters! Let's put the 's' and 'h' together, then add an 'i' and a 'p' to make the word 'ship'. See? The 's' and 'h' are working together to make the '/sh/' sound. Now let's try building some more!

slides.prompt: Build 6 words with 'sh': ship, shop, shin, shed, fish, wish. Read each one. Can you think of any other /sh/ words?
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be word builders! We're going to use our letters to make words that have the '/sh/' sound, like 'ship' and 'fish'. Let's build them together, and then we can try to read them. Can you think of any other words that have the '/sh/' sound? You're doing so great!

slides.text: 'When s and h come together, they make the special sound /sh/. These letter teams are called phonograms!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the /sh/ sound in words and build at least 4 words containing 'sh'?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned that when 's' and 'h' are together, they make the special '/sh/' sound. These pairs of letters that make one sound are called phonograms, and you are a super phonogram builder! You helped build so many words with '/sh/'!

parent_notes: This is a landmark lesson — the child's first phonogram! Phonograms (also called digraphs) are letter combinations that make a single sound different from either letter alone. 'Sh' is ideal as the first phonogram because the sound is distinct and familiar (the 'shh' gesture). In Montessori, phonogram letters are typically presented on green cards (vs. pink for single sounds and blue for blends). The key concept to convey: these two letters are a TEAM. They always make this sound together. Point out /sh/ everywhere you encounter it in daily life: 'Look! That sign says SHOP — there is our /sh/!' This builds phonic awareness naturally.

title: Golden Beads — Number Cards
description: The child learns to associate golden bead quantities with their written numeral symbols using number cards. Green cards for units (1-9), blue cards for tens (10-90), red cards for hundreds (100-900), and green cards for thousands (1000-9000).
instructions:
1. Present the number card set: units (green), tens (blue), hundreds (red), thousands (green).
2. Lay out unit cards 1-9. 'These tell us how many units.'
3. Lay out ten cards 10-90. 'Notice each one has a zero — that is the tens place!'
4. Lay out hundred cards 100-900. 'Two zeros — hundreds!'
5. Lay out thousand cards 1000-9000. 'Three zeros — thousands!'
6. Match cards to golden bead quantities: place '300' next to 3 hundred squares.
materials_needed: Golden bead number cards (units 1-9, tens 10-90, hundreds 100-900, thousands 1000-9000)

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is our special math time where we learn about numbers and how they look as tiny pictures. We're going to see how numbers are like secret codes for counting things!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay the mat out. Have cards in separate piles by category. Keep golden beads accessible.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some fun things for our math game today! See these colorful cards? Those are like number signs. And these shiny golden beads are like counting treasures! We'll put them all on this big mat so we have lots of space to play and learn.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we learned about golden bead quantities. Today we are going to learn the NUMBERS that go with them!' Show a unit bead and the card '1'. 'One unit — one!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember those golden beads we played with? They showed us how many things we have. Now, we're going to learn the special number that goes with each pile of beads, like how '1' goes with one little bead.

slides.text: Lay out green unit cards: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9. 'You already know these! These tell us how many units.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these green cards! These are like our counting friends for small numbers, from 1 all the way to 9. They show us exactly how many single beads we have, just like you know how to count them!

slides.text: Lay out blue ten cards: 10, 20, 30... 90. 'Each of these has ONE zero. The zero means there are no extra units — just tens!' Match 30 to 3 ten bars.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we have these blue cards, and they have a little '0' at the end. That '0' is like a special helper that tells us we have groups of ten beads, not just single ones. See how the card '30' matches three long bars of ten beads?

slides.text: Lay out red hundred cards: 100, 200... 900. 'Two zeros! Hundreds are big!' Then green thousand cards. 'THREE zeros — the biggest!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at these big numbers! The red cards have two zeros, and they mean we have big groups of one hundred beads – like a whole lot of treasures! And the green cards with three zeros are even bigger, for thousands of beads!

slides.prompt: Match game: pick a card, then fetch the matching golden bead quantity. Try: 40, 7, 200, 1000. Then reverse — pick beads and find the matching card!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a matching game! You can pick a number card, like '40', and then find the golden beads that match it. Or, you can pick a pile of beads and find the number card that tells us how many there are! You're going to be a super matcher!

slides.text: 'Now you can connect the golden beads to their numbers! Green for units, blue for tens, red for hundreds.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match number cards to golden bead quantities for all four categories?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job today connecting the numbers to the beads! You learned that green cards are for single beads, blue cards are for tens, red cards are for hundreds, and even bigger green cards are for thousands. You're becoming a math star!

parent_notes: The color-coding of number cards is a Montessori hallmark: green for units, blue for tens, red for hundreds (then green again for thousands, beginning the cycle). This color system appears throughout Montessori math materials and helps the child unconsciously absorb place value. The cards are sized so they can be overlaid — 300 (red) + 40 (blue) + 5 (green) stack to show 345. Today we just introduce the individual categories; composing multi-digit numbers comes next. Let the child freely explore the cards and beads. The sensorial connection between quantity and symbol is the essence of this work.

title: Grace and Courtesy — Offering Help
description: The child practices the social skill of offering help to others politely. Through role-playing scenarios, the child learns to notice when someone needs help and offer assistance using kind words and gentle actions.
instructions:
1. Discuss: 'Sometimes people around us need help. How can we tell? They might be struggling or look sad.'
2. Role play scenario 1: Parent pretends to carry too many books. 'May I help you carry some?'
3. Role play scenario 2: A younger sibling cannot reach something. 'Can I get that for you?'
4. Role play scenario 3: Someone spills something. 'I will help you clean that up.'
5. Practice the phrases: 'May I help you?' 'Can I help?' 'Let me help!'
6. Discuss: 'We also need to accept when someone says no, thank you.'
materials_needed: Props for role-playing (books, cup of water, blocks)

slides.heading: Grace and Courtesy
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is our special lesson about being a good friend and helper. We're going to learn how to be super kind and offer help when someone needs it!

items: Props: stack of books, cup, blocks
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare simple scenarios to act out. Keep it lighthearted and fun.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we get to play with! We have some books to pretend to carry, and some blocks to stack. We'll also need a nice open space, like our living room floor, to act out our helping game!

slides.text: 'Sometimes people need help. How can we tell? We use our eyes to notice and our words to offer.' Discuss clues: struggling, looking sad, being stuck.
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, our friends or grown-ups might need a little bit of help. We can use our eyes to see if they look like they are having a hard time, or maybe if they look a little bit sad. Then, we can use our kind words to ask if they need a hand!

slides.text: Scenario 1: Parent carries a tall stack of books and pretends to struggle. 'What could you say?' Teach the phrase: 'May I help you carry some?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pretend! Imagine Mommy or Daddy is carrying a big, tall stack of books, and they look like they might drop them! What a super kind thing to say would be, "May I help you carry some?"

slides.text: Scenario 2: Pretend a friend spills water. 'What can we do?' Model: 'Let me help you clean that up!' Get a towel together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh no, pretend someone spilled some water! What a nice thing to do is to help them clean it up. We can say, "Let me help you clean that up!" and then we can find a towel together to help make it dry again.

slides.text: 'Sometimes people say no thank you, I can do it myself. That is okay! We respect their answer. Offering is what matters.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, even when we want to help, someone might say, "No thank you, I can do it myself." And that's okay! We just smile and know that it was very kind of us to offer to help them.

slides.prompt: Let's switch! Now you pretend to need help and I will offer. Then you create a new scenario. Practice saying: 'May I help you?' and 'Can I help?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the helper! You can pretend you need help, and I will offer. Then, you can think of a new way to help someone, and practice saying "May I help you?" or "Can I help?" You're doing so great!

slides.text: 'Helpers make the world a kinder place. This week, look for chances to offer help — at home and out in the world!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify when someone needs help and offer politely using appropriate phrases?
slides.mascot_explanation: You learned how to be a wonderful helper today! Remember, offering help makes everyone feel happy and makes the world a kinder place. Keep your eyes open for people you can help this week!

parent_notes: Grace and courtesy lessons are a distinctive feature of Montessori education. Rather than simply telling children to be helpful, Montessori gives them explicit practice with the words and actions. Role-playing makes the abstract concept concrete. After this lesson, look for real opportunities throughout the week: 'I notice your dad is carrying groceries — what could you say?' Praise the child when you observe them spontaneously offering help. Also model offering help yourself, narrating what you are doing: 'I see you are having trouble with your zipper — may I help?' This teaches by example.

title: Read-Aloud: Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain by Verna Aardema
description: Reading this rhythmic, cumulative African tale about a herdsman who brings rain to the dry Kapiti Plain in Kenya. This connects to the Africa geography lesson and introduces the child to African storytelling traditions.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This story comes from Africa — Kenya, which is in East Africa.'
2. Find Kenya on the Africa map or globe.
3. Read the story with its rhythmic, cumulative pattern (similar to 'This is the House that Jack Built').
4. Encourage the child to join in on repeated phrases.
5. Discuss: 'Why did the plain need rain? What happened when the rain came?'
6. Talk about how different places have different amounts of rain.
materials_needed: Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain by Verna Aardema

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this colorful picture! We're going to read a special story called "Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain." It's going to be so much fun!

items: Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain
slides.setup_instructions: Have the globe or map nearby to point out Kenya before reading.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need a few things to get ready for our story. We need the book, of course! We also need a map or a globe so we can find where our story happens. And we need a super cozy spot to snuggle up and read together.

slides.text: 'This story comes all the way from AFRICA — from a country called Kenya. Let's find it on our map!' Point to Kenya on the Africa puzzle map or globe.
slides.mascot_explanation: This story comes from a faraway place called Kenya, which is in Africa! Let's find Kenya on our map together. See this big continent? Kenya is right here!

slides.text: Read with rhythm and energy. The cumulative pattern builds — encourage the child to say the repeated lines with you.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to read our story! Listen to how the words sound, they're like music! When you hear a part that repeats, try to say it with me! It's like a fun game!

slides.text: Pause: 'The grass was dry and the cows were thin. Why? Because there was no RAIN. What do you think will happen?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh no, the story says the grass is all dry and the cows are skinny. Why do you think that is? What do you think will happen when the rain finally comes?

slides.prompt: After reading: 'Can you retell the story? First the plain was dry, then...' Talk about what plants and animals need rain for. Why is water so important?
slides.mascot_explanation: After our story, we'll talk all about it! Can you tell me what happened first in the story? And why do you think the plants and animals needed the rain so much? Water is super important for everyone!

slides.text: 'This story came from Kenya in Africa. People everywhere tell stories about nature and weather — because nature matters to all of us!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the basic story and explain why rain was important for the plain?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wasn't that a great story? It came from Kenya, which is in Africa. People everywhere love to tell stories about the world around us, like the weather and animals, because it's all so important to us! You did a wonderful job listening!

parent_notes: This Nandi tale from Kenya has a cumulative structure similar to Western nursery rhymes, showing the child that storytelling patterns exist across cultures. The rhythmic, repetitive text is excellent for developing phonological awareness and prediction skills. By connecting this book to the Africa puzzle map lesson, you create a cross-curricular experience that deepens understanding. Children often want to hear cumulative tales multiple times, which is beneficial for language development. The theme of rain and drought connects to science concepts about what living things need.

title: Fabric Box — Tactile Exploration
description: The child matches pairs of fabric squares by touch alone, using a blindfold. This sensorial exercise isolates the sense of touch and develops tactile discrimination, vocabulary for textures, and concentration.
instructions:
1. Present the fabric box containing matched pairs: silk, cotton, wool, linen, velvet, corduroy.
2. First, feel each pair with eyes open. Name the textures: 'This is silk — smooth and slippery. This is wool — soft and slightly rough.'
3. Blindfold the child (or have them close eyes).
4. Place one fabric from each pair on the left, the matching ones on the right.
5. Child picks up a fabric from the left, feels it carefully, then searches the right pile for its match.
6. Remove blindfold to check matches.
materials_needed: Fabric box with 6 pairs of fabric squares (silk, cotton, wool, linen, velvet, corduroy)

slides.heading: Fabric Box
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we're going to play a special game called "Fabric Box" where we use our super-duper sense of touch! We'll be matching soft and bumpy things just by feeling them with our fingers.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all 12 fabric squares. Separate into two groups — one of each pair on the left, partners on the right.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these soft and scratchy things! We have a special box with different pieces of fabric, and a soft blindfold that will help us play. We also have a mat to keep everything tidy while we work. Can you help your grown-up find these special things?

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use ONLY our sense of touch — our fingers will be our eyes!' Show the fabrics with eyes open first.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get ready to feel things with our fingers! We're going to close our eyes, or you can wear this soft blindfold, so our fingers have to do all the looking for us today. It's like a secret mission for your hands!

slides.text: Feel each one together: 'This is silk — so smooth it slips through your fingers. This is wool — feel the tiny bumps. This is velvet — like petting a cat!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's touch these special fabrics with our eyes open first. Feel this one – it's so smooth, like a silky ribbon! And this one feels a little bumpy, like a fluffy sheep's wool. It's so fun to feel all the different ways they feel!

slides.text: Put on the blindfold. 'Pick up one fabric from this side. Feel it very carefully. Now find its twin on the other side — using only your fingers!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put on our blindfold, or you can close your eyes really tight! Pick up one of these fuzzy pieces from this side, and feel it all over with your fingers. Then, try to find its matching twin on the other side, just by feeling!

slides.text: After matching all pairs, remove the blindfold. 'Let's see how you did! Did you match them correctly?' Celebrate successes.
slides.mascot_explanation: All done? Let's take off the blindfold and see if your amazing fingers found all the right matches! Yay! Look, you found them! Your fingers did such a good job feeling all the different textures.

slides.prompt: Match all 6 pairs by touch alone! Take your time — feel each fabric carefully between your fingers. Which was easiest to match? Which was hardest?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the fun part where you get to be the texture detective! Pick up a fabric, feel it with your fingers, and then find its match on the other side. Take your time and feel them super carefully – you can do it! Which one feels the smoothest?

slides.text: 'Your fingers can tell the difference between many textures! Silk is smooth, wool is fuzzy, corduroy has ridges. You have very sensitive hands!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 4 of 6 fabric pairs by touch alone?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Your fingers are so smart and can feel all the special differences between the fabrics. You found out which ones are smooth, which ones are bumpy, and which ones have little lines. Your hands are amazing detectives!

parent_notes: The fabric matching exercise is a classic Montessori sensorial activity that isolates the tactile sense. Using a blindfold heightens concentration and forces the child to rely entirely on touch. If the child is uncomfortable with a blindfold, they can simply close their eyes. Make your own fabric box: cut identical 4-inch squares from fabric scraps. Choose textures with clear differences at first (silk vs. burlap) and add more similar ones as the child develops skill. This work develops the vocabulary of texture: smooth, rough, soft, bumpy, ridged, silky, fuzzy — all words the child can use in writing and observation.

title: Sandpaper Letters — Group 4 Continued (x, y, k)
description: Introduction to three more sandpaper letters: x, y, and k. These are less common letters, but the child now has the experience and confidence to learn multiple letters efficiently. This completes most of the single letter sounds.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'x'. Trace while saying /ks/. 'X usually comes at the END of words — fox, box, six.'
2. Present 'y'. Trace while saying /y/ (as in 'yes'). Three-period lesson.
3. Present 'k'. Trace while saying /k/. 'K makes the same sound as c! We will learn when to use each one later.'
4. Review all known letters (now 21 of 26).
5. Build words: fox, box, six, yak, yam, yes, kit, kid, keg.
6. Celebrate: 'You know almost all the letter sounds!'

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letters
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we're going to learn three more special letters that help us read and write. We're going to learn about the letters x, y, and k. They are like new friends for our alphabet family!

slides.setup_instructions: Present new letters one at a time. Have the sand tray available for extra practice.
slides.mascot_explanation: To do our special letter work, we need a few things. We have our new sandpaper letters: x, y, and k. We also have our old letters we already know, and a special box of letters to build words. And look, here's our sand tray for practicing!

slides.text: Letter 'x': trace the cross shape. '/ks/ — like the end of fox and box.' Note: x usually appears at the end of words!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's meet the letter 'x'! See how it looks like a big cross? We're going to trace it with our fingers like this, and say the sound it makes: /ks/. It's like the end of the word 'fox' or 'box'!

slides.text: Letter 'y': trace the two diagonal strokes meeting and the tail going down. '/y/ — like the beginning of yes and yellow.' Three-period lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's another new friend, the letter 'y'! Trace it with me, going down and then making a little tail. This letter makes the /y/ sound, like at the beginning of 'yes' or 'yellow'!

slides.text: Letter 'k': trace the tall stroke and the two angled lines. '/k/ — like the beginning of kite and king.' Note: 'K and c make the same sound!'
slides.mascot_explanation: And here is our last new letter for today, 'k'! Trace this tall line and then the two little slanted lines that go into it. The letter 'k' makes the /k/ sound, just like in 'kite' or 'king'. It sounds the same as the letter 'c'!

slides.text: 'You now know 21 letter sounds — that is almost the whole alphabet! Let's build some new words.' Build fox, yak, kit.
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray! You know so many letter sounds now, 21 of them! That's almost the whole alphabet! Let's use our special letters to build some new words like 'fox', 'yak', and 'kit'.

slides.prompt: Build these words: fox, box, six, yam, yes, kit, kid. Read each one! Then write your favorite in the sand tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to build some fun words with our letters! Let's make 'fox', 'box', 'six', 'yam', 'yes', 'kit', and 'kid'. After we build them, we can pick our favorite one and write it in the sand tray!

slides.text: 'Twenty-one sounds! You are SO close to knowing every letter in the alphabet. Just a few more to go!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace and produce the sounds for x, y, and k, and build words containing them?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You learned three more letter sounds, and now you know 21 sounds in total! That means you are super close to knowing all the letters in the whole alphabet! We learned about 'x', 'y', and 'k' today!

parent_notes: These three letters present interesting teaching opportunities. The letter x is unusual because it typically makes the /ks/ sound and almost always appears at the end of words in early reading (fox, box, mix, six). The letter y can function as both a consonant (yes, you) and a vowel (my, funny) — for now, teach only the consonant sound. The letter k duplicates the /k/ sound of c, which can be confusing. Simply acknowledge this: 'Both c and k can say /k/. You will learn the rules for when to use each one as you read more.' This honest approach prevents frustration later.

title: Golden Beads — Composing Numbers
description: The child composes multi-digit numbers by combining golden bead quantities and overlaying number cards. For example, building 2,345 using 2 thousand cubes, 3 hundred squares, 4 ten bars, and 5 unit beads, then overlaying the cards 2000 + 300 + 40 + 5.
instructions:
1. 'Let's build a big number! We need 2 thousands, 3 hundreds, 4 tens, and 5 units.'
2. Child fetches each category from the golden bead bank.
3. Verify: count 2 thousand cubes, 3 hundred squares, 4 ten bars, 5 unit beads.
4. Now find the matching number cards: 2000, 300, 40, 5.
5. Overlay the cards: stack 2000 + 300 + 40 + 5. 'Read the number: two thousand, three hundred forty-five!'
6. Repeat with 2-3 more numbers.

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, friend! This is our special math time where we learn about BIG numbers! We're going to use shiny golden beads to make them.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the golden bead bank on a shelf. Lay number cards sorted by category on the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special things we need! We have a golden bead bank to get our beads from, and cool number cards to put together. We also have a big mat to play on and a tray to carry our treasures. Ask your grown-up to help you find these special things so we can start our game!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to build BIG numbers — numbers with thousands, hundreds, tens, AND units!' Eyes light up!
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we get to build super-duper big numbers! We're going to use special golden beads that stand for thousands, hundreds, tens, and even little ones called units. It's like building with blocks, but for numbers!

slides.text: 'Please bring me 2 thousands.' Child fetches 2 cubes. 'Now 3 hundreds.' Child fetches 3 squares. 'Now 4 tens and 5 units.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our building blocks ready! Can you go get two of the big thousand cubes? Great job! Now, let's find three of the flat hundred squares, then four long ten bars, and finally five tiny little unit beads.

slides.text: Lay everything on the mat. 'Let's find the number cards. 2 thousands — that is 2000.' Find the red 2000 card. '3 hundreds — 300. 4 tens — 40. 5 units — 5.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we put our golden beads on the big mat. We have our thousands, our hundreds, our tens, and our units all together! Next, we find the special cards that match our beads: a card for 2000, a card for 300, a card for 40, and a card for 5.

slides.text: Stack the cards: place 2000 down, overlay 300 (covering the zeros), overlay 40, overlay 5. 'Read the number: 2,345! Two thousand, three hundred forty-five!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch this! We're going to stack our number cards right on top of each other. We put the biggest number, 2000, down first, then put the 300 card on top, then the 40 card, and finally the 5 card. Now, let's read our giant number together: two thousand, three hundred forty-five!

slides.prompt: Build these numbers with beads and cards: 1,234 then 3,521 then 4,106 (tricky — no tens!). For each one, fetch the beads, find the cards, and read the number aloud.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the number builder! We're going to make some more amazing numbers. First, let's make 1,234, then 3,521, and then try the tricky one, 4,106! Remember to get the right beads and put the matching cards on top, and then say the number out loud. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You can build numbers in the THOUSANDS! The beads show the quantity, the cards show the symbol. Together they make the whole number.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compose at least 2 multi-digit numbers using golden beads and overlaid number cards?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You built numbers all the way into the thousands, all by yourself! You used the golden beads to show how many and the number cards to show the numbers. You are such a super math star, and building those big numbers was the coolest!

parent_notes: This is one of the most powerful lessons in Montessori math. The overlay of number cards physically demonstrates place value: 2000 + 300 + 40 + 5 = 2345. The child sees that 2345 is not just a string of digits but a composition of different-sized quantities. The number card overlay is ingenious — each card has the right number of zeros, and stacking them creates the composite number. Watch for the concept of zero as a placeholder: in 4,106, there are no tens (the tens place is 0). This is a subtle but crucial concept that the golden beads make visible — there are simply no ten bars on the mat.

title: Animal Classification — Vertebrates and Invertebrates
description: The child learns the fundamental division of the animal kingdom: animals with backbones (vertebrates) and animals without (invertebrates). Using figurines and pictures, the child sorts animals into these two groups.
